title: How to Grow Beans in Cotton

steps.title: Choose the types of dry beans you want to grow.
steps.content: Choose the types of dry beans you want to grow. You can grow any type of dry bean using cotton balls. Purchase a packet of bean seeds if you want instructions for how to grow them in the ground after they sprout, or use any type of whole, dry beans if you just want to experiment. [1] X Research source To keep the plant compact, opt for a bush bean plant. This will not require a trellis or pole to support it and it will only grow to about 2 ft (0.61 m). If you opt for pole beans, then the vine may grow to 15 ft (4.6 m), so it will need plenty of room to climb. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Soak the beans in water overnight to speed up the growing process.
steps.content: Soak the beans in water overnight to speed up the growing process. Place the beans into a bowl or cup and fill it with water. Then, let the beans soak in the water at room temperature overnight. This will help to soften up the outer shells of the beans and make it easier for the plants to sprout. [3] X Research source Don’t use hot water as this could partially cook the beans. Use cool or lukewarm tap water.

steps.title: Fill a plastic cup or glass jar about 3/4 full of cotton balls[4] X Expert Source Olivia ChoongPlant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. .
steps.content: Fill a plastic cup or glass jar about 3/4 full of cotton balls [4] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. . Don’t pack the cotton balls down. Keep them loose in the cup or jar. Fill it until the topmost cotton balls are about 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) from the top of the jar or cup. [5] X Research source You can also place the beans into plastic baggies if you don’t have any cups or jars to use. [6] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. However, you’ll have to transfer the bean sprouts to a jar, plastic cup, or the ground once they run out of room. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Moisten the cotton balls with water so they are just damp.
steps.content: Moisten the cotton balls with water so they are just damp. [8] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. Drizzle about 1 ⁄ 8 to 1 ⁄ 4 c (30 to 59 mL) of water over the cotton balls to wet them. Don’t add too much water, as the beans might rot and not sprout. [9] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. Only add enough to moisten the cotton balls without excess water in the bottom of the cup. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Space 2-3 beans 1 in (2.5 cm) apart on an indentation in the cotton.
steps.content: Space 2-3 beans 1 in (2.5 cm) apart on an indentation in the cotton. Poke your finger into the cotton to make a shallow indentation for the bean seed to rest in. Make 2 to 3 indentations per cup that are 1 in (2.5 cm) apart from each other. Place the beans just on top of the indentations in the cotton. Don’t push them down into the cotton or burrow them inside of a cotton ball. [11] X Research source Don’t try to sprout more than 3 beans per cup as they will not have enough room to grow.

steps.title: Place the beans in a sunny spot for 30 minutes per day and a well-lit area the rest of the time.
steps.content: Place the beans in a sunny spot for 30 minutes per day and a well-lit area the rest of the time. [12] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. The beans will need to get 30 minutes of bright sunlight each day and then you can transfer them to a well-lit spot that is not in direct sunlight for the rest of the day. This is important since too much sunlight can stop the seeds from sprouting. [13] X Research source Do not place the beans in a dark place, such as a cupboard.

steps.title: Water the beans when the cotton starts to get dry.
steps.content: Water the beans when the cotton starts to get dry. [14] X Expert Source Olivia Choong Plant & Gardening Specialist Expert Interview. 3 September 2021. In warm temperatures, you may need to do this every 2 days, and in cold temperatures, you may only need to water them 2 times per week. [15] X Research source If the beans don’t sprout, this may be because they are not getting enough sunlight or because the cotton is too dry or too wet.

steps.title: Watch for the beans to sprout after about 3 days.
steps.content: Watch for the beans to sprout after about 3 days. The beans should start to sprout by this point, but if not, keep watching them for a few more days. If nothing happens within 1 week, start over with new beans. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Plant the sprouts and cotton in soil when they're 8 in (20 cm) tall.
steps.content: Plant the sprouts and cotton in soil when they're 8 in (20 cm) tall. Measure the bean plants once per week to track their growth. They’re ready to transfer when they are 8 in (20 cm) tall. Keep the bean sprouts with the cotton you planted them in when you are ready to transfer them to the ground. [17] X Research source Do not separate the bean roots from the cotton or you may kill the plants.

steps.title: Space bush beans 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) apart with 2.5 to 3 ft (0.76 to 0.91 m) between rows.
steps.content: Space bush beans 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) apart with 2.5 to 3 ft (0.76 to 0.91 m) between rows. Use a ruler or tape measure to check the distances. Dig the holes deep enough so that they will cover the cotton and bean roots completely. Then, transfer each of the bean plants and cotton to one of the holes. Cover the cotton with about 1 in (2.5 cm) of soil. [18] X Research source Spacing the beans too close together may cause them not to grow, so make sure that they are at least 3 in (7.6 cm) apart.

steps.title: Plant 6 pole beans around poles spaced 3 to 4 ft (0.91 to 1.22 m) apart.
steps.content: Plant 6 pole beans around poles spaced 3 to 4 ft (0.91 to 1.22 m) apart. Make a mound of dirt and then thrust a 6 to 8 ft (1.8 to 2.4 m) tall pole through the center of it. Plant the 6 bean plants in a circle around the pole so that each plant is equidistant from the pole—about 6–8 in (15–20 cm) from it—and the other plants. Dig the holes deep enough to cover the cotton and bean roots completely. Then, transfer each of the plants to the holes and cover the cotton with about 1 in (2.5 cm) of soil. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Water the beans once per week in dry weather or when the soil is dry.
steps.content: Water the beans once per week in dry weather or when the soil is dry. Right after you first plant the beans, water them well. Then, check the beans on a weekly basis or more often in very hot, dry weather. If it rains, you can skip watering them for up to 1 week, so check the weather forecast often. [20] X Research source You can check the soil by inserting your finger 1 in (2.5 cm) into it next to a bean plant. If it feels dry, it’s time to water the plants.

steps.title: Fertilize the soil around the plants with a 10-20-10 fertilizer.
steps.content: Fertilize the soil around the plants with a 10-20-10 fertilizer. Spread the fertilizer over the soil around the plants and between the rows. Use 2 to 3 lb (0.91 to 1.36 kg) of fertilizer per 10 by 10 ft (3.0 by 3.0 m) area of earth. Mix the fertilizer in with the top 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) of soil around the plants. [21] X Research source You can purchase 10-20-10 fertilizer in a home improvement store or nursery.

steps.title: Pick the beans when they are ready to harvest.
steps.content: Pick the beans when they are ready to harvest. Tug gently to remove the beans from the plant so that you do not damage it. The plant may continue to grow beans after the first harvest. The amount of time it takes for the beans to be ready will depend on the type of beans you are growing, so check your seed packet if you’re unsure. For example, green beans are ready when they are about the size of a pencil. Be careful not to let the beans get any bigger than this as they will become tough and stringy. [22] X Research source
